channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Lost Ground in the East Creates Stark Choices for Ukraine
item.description: Its military leaders are increasingly confronting the question of whether to withdraw from frontline cities to preserve soldiers’ lives, even if it means a more brutal fight to regain them.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents collecting water from a municipal pump in Sloviansk, Ukraine, on Monday. Strikes have left much of the city without running water.

item.title: U.K. Live Updates: Boris Johnson Could Still Falter From Political Upheaval or the Economy
item.description: Despite surviving a no-confidence vote in Parliament, Britain’s prime minister must now weather a risky Parliamentary by-election this month and, potentially, even a rebellion by his fellow Conservative lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Johnson survived a vote of confidence by Tory lawmakers on Monday.

item.title: Philippines Struggles to Save Monument of Heroes Museum
item.description: Organizers at the Monument of Heroes in the Philippines are racing to preserve documents related to the Marcos regime before the dictator’s son takes office.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ezra Acayan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors at the Monument of Heroes, a museum in the Philippines dedicated to victims of martial law.

item.title: Violence in Rural Mexico Ensnares Doctors, Causing Worker Shortages
item.description: As criminal organizations control more territory in less-populated regions, health care workers, caught in the crossfire, grow reluctant to work in such places.
item.dc:creator: Steve Fisher
item.media:description: Mexican soldiers patrolled a road in the state of Zacatecas in March, responding to an increase in violence in the municipality of Jerez de Garcia Salinas.

item.title: A Domestic Political Fight in Sweden Gets Embroiled in Geopolitics
item.description: A move by right-wing lawmakers to remove Sweden’s justice minister has been dragged into a battle over the country’s efforts to join NATO.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Anders Wiklund/TT News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Justice Minister Morgan Johansson, center, after surviving a no-confidence vote in the Swedish Parliament on Tuesday.

item.title: Gupta Brothers, Accused of Corruption in South Africa, Are Arrested in Dubai
item.description: Atul and Rajesh Gupta had fled South Africa four years ago amid intense law enforcement scrutiny and public outrage over allegations that they facilitated the gutting of state resources.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Joao Silva for The New York Times
item.media:description: Atul Gupta in Johannesburg in 2010. He and his brother Rajesh have been accused of facilitating public corruption and gutting state resources in South Africa.

item.title: Ukrainian Officials Move to Rechristen Landmarks With Russian Names
item.description: Across the country, officials are evaluating and rechristening roads, parks and other sites bearing Russian names.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A street named after the classical composer Tchaikovsky in Lviv, Ukraine.

item.title: How Boris Johnson Shattered His Own Invincibility
item.description: The prime minister survived a no-confidence vote, but has been politically wounded by the same baffling mix of strengths and foibles that propelled his rise: rare political intuition, and breathtaking personal recklessness.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Rebels in the conservative party have called for a no-confidence vote that could cost Prime Minister Boris Johnson his job.

item.title: Bangladesh Firefighters Unaware of Chemicals Stored at Shipping Container Depot
item.description: Nine firefighters were among at least 41 people killed in a blaze and a subsequent series of explosions.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Emily Schmall
item.media:description: The BM Inland Container Depot in Chittagong, Bangladesh, on Tuesday.

item.title: China Tries to Keep Covid Out of Its Grueling College Entrance Exams
item.description: Some students have to travel from locked-down areas to testing sites in special vehicles, while others might be isolated for the exam.
item.dc:creator: John Liu
item.media:description: Students arriving for the college entrance exams, known as the gaokao, in Nanjing, China, on Tuesday.

item.title: Potent Weapons Reach Ukraine Faster Than the Know-How to Use Them
item.description: Soldiers desperate for advanced arms to match their Russian enemies have resorted to Google Translate to decipher the instructions for their sophisticated new tools.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery unit with their aging antitank gun in the Kherson region.

item.title: British Tourist Gets 15 Years in Iraqi Jail for Taking Shards From Archaeology Site
item.description: The retired geologist said he did not know it was illegal to take the pottery shards when he picked them up from the site. The harshness of his sentence came as a surprise.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:description: James Fitton (center left), a retired British geologist, and Volker Waldmann (center right), a German psychologist, arrive at a Baghdad courthouse where Mr. Fitton was sentenced.

item.title: Assassinations Become Weapon of Choice for Guerrilla Groups in Myanmar
item.description: A movement to restore democracy has evolved into deadly warfare between a ruthless military and a resistance force with limited weaponry.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Members of the People’s Defense Force, the armed wing of the civilian National Unity Government opposed to Myanmar’s ruling military regime, taking part in training at a camp near the Myanmar-Thai border last year.

item.title: Israel’s Government Teeters Again, Losing Vote on Law that Supports West Bank Settlers
item.description: The vote’s failure — from defections within the governing bloc and a power move by usually pro-settler opposition lawmakers — could topple the government and throw a lifeline to former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley

item.title: As the Great Salt Lake Dries Up, Utah Faces ‘An Environmental Nuclear Bomb’
item.description: Climate change and rapid population growth are shrinking the lake, creating a bowl of toxic dust that could poison the air around Salt Lake City.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle and Bryan Tarnowski
item.media:credit: Bryan Tarnowski for The New York Times

item.title: Before Chickens Were Nuggets, They Were Revered
item.description: The origin of the domestic fowl is more recent than previously thought, but it may have taken them thousands of years to become food.
item.dc:creator: James Gorman
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.media:description: Domesticated chickens are descendants of the red jungle fowl, and scientists suspect they were first viewed by humans as marvelous and exotic.

item.title: Ukraine and Russia Exchange War Dead Remains
item.description: In the first official confirmed exchange of war dead, Russia and Ukraine each received about 160 bodies.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: The Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol last month.

item.title: Democratic Lawmakers Urge Biden to Ensure Saudi Ties Serve U.S.
item.description: A letter to President Biden ahead of his planned trip to Saudi Arabia raises concerns about the kingdom’s cooperation with China on ballistic missiles and its human rights violations.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Edward Wong
item.media:description: As Saudi Arabia and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman came under increasing criticism after the killing of Jamal Khashoggi, the kingdom stepped up its work with China.

item.title: The prime minister will also have to grapple with an economy at risk of recession.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Alice Zoo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The financial district in London.

item.title: The Global Minimum Tax Deal Is in Trouble
item.description: A global agreement to increase taxes on corporations is in jeopardy.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Lexey Swall for The New York Times
item.media:description: The experts Itai Grinberg and Rebecca Kysar worked on a global tax deal.

item.title: Theresa May and Others Who Survived No-Confidence Votes Didn’t Last Long After
item.description: Two previous Conservative prime ministers were ultimately forced out, and one lost a landslide election two years later.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Theresa May giving her final speech as Britain’s prime minister in 2019. Mrs. May survived a vote of confidence, but later stepped down after failing to get her Brexit plan through Parliament.

item.title: Fiji Hands Over Superyacht That U.S. Says Is Tied to Russian Oligarch
item.description: The handover of the Amadea is the latest development in a global effort to seize the assets of oligarchs with ties to Russia’s president.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Leon Lord/Fiji Sun, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The superyacht Amadea docked in Lautoka, Fiji, in April.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A no-confidence vote against Boris Johnson.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain last month.

item.title: British Journalist and Brazilian Indigenous Expert Missing in the Amazon
item.description: Dom Phillips and Bruno Araújo Pereira were last seen Sunday morning traveling in a boat in the northern Brazilian state of Amazonas.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Manuela Andreoni
item.media:description: Dom Phillips, center, talking to two Indigenous men in Aldeia Maloca Papiú, Roraima State, Brazil, in 2019.

item.title: How ‘Trustless’ Is Bitcoin, Really?
item.description: In myth, the cryptocurrency is egalitarian, decentralized and all but anonymous. The reality is very different, scientists have found.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Boris Johnson Stays in Power
item.description: Britain’s prime minister survived a no-confidence vote.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: Boris Johnson Survives Confidence Vote, Scarred but Still Standing
item.description: More than 40 percent of lawmakers in Mr. Johnson’s own Conservative Party voted to remove him, a sign that he may struggle to remain prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain last month.

item.title: Pete Buttigieg Tests Positive for Coronavirus
item.description: Mr. Buttigieg, who a White House spokesman said was not considered a close contact of President Biden, is at least the fifth cabinet secretary to test positive in about the last month.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Secretary Pete Buttigieg was not considered a close contact of President Biden, a White House spokesman said on Monday.

item.title: Boris Johnson Makes His Case in Speech to Conservatives: ‘We Can Unite’
item.description: In a speech to his fellow Conservatives, the prime minister warned against “pointless fratricidal debate.”
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson last month after taking questions in Parliament.

item.title: Ukraine Insurgents Strike in Russia-Occupied Regions
item.description: Fueled by brutal Russian repression and worsening humanitarian conditions, Ukrainian partisans appear to be striking deep inside Russian-controlled territory.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A photograph taken during a trip organized by the Russian military showed a Russian serviceman near the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Station in Enerhodar, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: High-tech Western Weapons Pose Challenges for Ukraine Military
item.description: Ukrainian fighters are getting increasingly sophisticated weaponry from abroad. Some have been reduced to Googling instructions.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier covering the artillery unit’s antitank gun with camouflage.

item.title: Mexico’s President Obrador Will Not Attend Americas Summit
item.description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico said he made the decision because Cuba, Nicaragua and Venezuela were not invited.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador said Monday he will not attend the summit.

item.title: Battered by Russian Shells, a Monastery Remains Loyal to Moscow
item.description: The monks and nuns cloistered in a monastery complex in eastern Ukraine absorb daily bombardments from Russian artillery. And yet they remain loyal to the Russian Orthodox Church.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A monk in the doorway of a building heavily damaged by Russian artillery at the Sviatohirsk monastery complex on Friday.

item.title: A political escape artist finds his career on the brink.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces a vote of confidence on Monday night.

item.title: British pound and stocks rise as vote on prime minister washes over markets.
item.description: Markets are moved more by global concerns, like the war in Ukraine, than by domestic political infighting.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson

item.title: Tropical Storm Alex Drifts Into the Atlantic After Flooding Florida
item.description: The storm brought rain and strong winds to Bermuda before becoming a post-tropical cyclone.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Jesus Jiménez
item.media:credit: Pedro Portal/Miami Herald, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rainfall from the weather system that would become Tropical Storm Alex flooded the Brickell area near downtown Miami on Saturday.

item.title: A Post-Roe America
item.description: We look at what abortion access would look like.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: The last abortion clinic on the Texas-Mexico border.

item.title: Behold the Lionfish, as Transfixing as It Is Destructive
item.description: Lionfish, while spectacularly beautiful, are wreaking havoc on Caribbean reef habitats.
item.dc:creator: Lorenzo Mittiga
item.media:description: A sting from the fish’s long, venomous spines is extremely painful but rarely fatal.

item.title: Britain’s prime minister, beset by a scandal over lockdown parties, faces a decisive vote.
item.description: Members of the British leader’s party reached a threshold to hold the vote, after he had come under fire about claims he misled Parliament about Downing Street parties during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle

item.title: Here are the latest developments from the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Britain’s Jubilee celebrations.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising in Kyiv on Sunday after explosions were heard in the early morning.

item.title: Russia Seeks Buyers for Plundered Ukraine Grain, U.S. Warns
item.description: American diplomats have alerted 14 countries, most in Africa, that Russian ships filled with stolen Ukrainian grain could be headed their way, posing a dilemma to countries facing dire food shortages.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: A satellite image showing a bulk carrier ship taking on grain at the Russian-controlled port of Sevastopol, Crimea, on May 19.

item.title: Struggling in Ukraine’s East, Russian Forces Strike in Kyiv
item.description: Vladimir Putin threatened “to strike targets we haven’t hit before” if Western nations proceed with plans to send long-range missiles to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A crater left from a Russian missile strike on the outskirts of Druzhkivka, in eastern Ukraine, on Sunday. One woman was killed, a regional official said.

item.title: Dozens Feared Dead in Church Attack in Owo, Nigeria
item.description: Gunmen fired on Catholics celebrating Mass in a usually peaceful part of the country. There was no claim of responsibility and the motive was unclear.
item.dc:creator: Ben Ezeamalu and Elian Peltier
item.media:description: At least four attackers stormed St. Francis Catholic Church in Owo, Nigeria, on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Russian Missiles Hit Kyiv
item.description: Plus Hindus try to flee Kashmir and Taipei commemorates Tiananmen Square.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising in the Darnytsky district in Kyiv, on Sunday.

item.title: Queen’s Jubilee Celebrations Offers Britons Respite From Woes
item.description: The Platinum Jubilee celebrations ended Sunday. Monday political and economic unease returns.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Members of the royal family joined Queen Elizabeth II on the balcony of Buckingham Palace on Sunday, the last of four days of celebrations to mark the Platinum Jubilee.

item.title: The Jack Welch Effect
item.description: His ruthlessness as General Electric’s C.E.O. was ultimately bad for the company, a new book argues.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times
item.media:description: Jack Welch before his retirement in 2001.

item.title: Dozens Killed and Hundreds Burned in Bangladesh Depot Disaster
item.description: A fire set off a series of explosions, killing at least 49 people, including firefighters. Many others were in critical condition.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: Firefighters on Sunday were still trying to contain a blaze that began late Saturday night at a container depot in Sitakunda, Bangladesh.

item.title: New Zealand’s Biodiversity Crisis Prompts Extreme Measures
item.description: A few years ago, the nation vowed to rid itself of most imported predators. But now some people are asking if that goal is feasible, or worth what it will cost.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie and Jim Huylebroek
item.media:description: Louis Davidson with Predator Free Wellington, setting up a trap on a coastal part of the Miramar Peninsula, south of New Zealand’s capital, Wellington.

item.title: Putin Ally Mines Gold and Plays Favorites in Sudan
item.description: Backed by the Kremlin, the shadowy network known as the Wagner Group is getting rich in Sudan while helping the military to crush a democracy movement.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Abdulmonam Eassa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian gold processing plant in the desert outside al-Ibediyya, 200 miles north of the Sudanese capital, Khartoum.

item.title: U.S. and South Korea Launch Missiles In Response to North Korean Tests
item.description: The North’s latest test, involving eight missiles, came a day after the United States and South Korea finished joint naval exercises in the East China Sea.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: KCNA via KNS, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, in April. The North has carried out 18 weapons tests this year.

item.title: Ukraine aims to restart soccer leagues on its own soil in August.
item.description: In an interview with The Associated Press, the leader of Ukraine’s soccer federation said President Volodymyr Zelensky had approved the decision.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather

item.title: U.S. Warship Arrives in Stockholm for Military Exercises, and as a Warning
item.description: For Sweden and Finland, which want to join NATO, the U.S.S. Kearsarge is a promise of the protection that membership in the alliance would bring against President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Fredrik Sandberg/TT News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Watching the U.S.S. Kearsarge arrive in Stockholm on Thursday.

item.title: As Battles Rage, Ukraine Rejects Macron Plea Not to ‘Humiliate’ Russia
item.description: Amid reports of battlefield gains by Ukraine, an official angrily rejected Mr. Macron’s advice, saying it “can only humiliate France.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at a frontline position near Donetsk in eastern Ukraine on Saturday.

item.title: Ukraine Official Says Forces Pushed Back Russians in Eastern City
item.description: Ukrainian forces poured men and armor toward the front line in Sievierodonetsk on Friday, and a military official said Ukrainian troops had managed to push Russian forces back by 20 percent.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A jet, most likely Russian, fired flares over Ukrainian frontline positions in May.

item.title: Senior Iranian Officer Dies, Leaving Questions About His Death
item.description: Col. Ali Esmaelzadeh was the second high-ranking officer of the same unit to die in a week. The circumstances were unclear, and Iranian news media provided conflicting reports.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Members of Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Corps in an annual military parade in Tehran in 2018.

item.title: In the U.K., Migrants From Hong Kong Build a New Life
item.description: More than a year after they first began arriving in Britain under a new visa program, people from Hong Kong are settling into their new home. But they still long for the one they left behind.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kago Ng; her husband, Valen Liu; and their son, Kaspar, enjoying a traditional Hong Kong hotpot in their apartment in Sutton, England, where they moved last year.
